study_goal: The researchers aimed to report and review dietary supplements associated with hepatotoxicity, including 1,3-Dimethylamylamine.
results_summary: The study identified 1,3-Dimethylamylamine as one of the single-ingredient dietary supplements associated with liver injury, but did not provide specific details on its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of dietary supplement users)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the timing of 5-HTP and L-DOPA administration affects gonadal growth and regression in Japanese quail under varying photoperiods.
results_summary: The study found that 5-HTP and L-DOPA administration significantly increased cloacal gland size under intermediate day length and slowed regression under short days, suggesting a reset of endogenous seasonal mechanisms.
population_specificity: Sexually immature Japanese quail raised under short photoperiod (LD8:16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether valproate increases central serotonin metabolism in manic patients by examining cortisol responses to L-5-HTP.
results_summary: L-5-HTP administration significantly increased cortisol responses in manic patients both before and after valproate treatment, with higher responses post-treatment, suggesting valproate may enhance central serotonergic neurotransmission.
population_specificity: 10 manic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the central and peripheral mechanisms by which 5-HTP reduces ethanol consumption and induces conditioned taste aversions (CTAs).
results_summary: 5-HTP decreased ethanol intake and induced persistent aversion, with central actions mediating initial inhibition and peripheral actions linked to persistent avoidance. Xylamidine and methysergide modulated these effects, suggesting both central and peripheral components.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models based on methodology).
interactions: Xylamidine and methysergide interacted with 5-HTP's effects; lithium was also studied in CTAs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 11C-5-HTP uptake could aid in diagnosing and monitoring metastatic hormone-refractory prostatic adenocarcinoma.
results_summary: Increased 11C-5-HTP uptake was observed in all skeletal lesions, with significant differences between normal bone and metastases. Uptake kinetics showed initial increase followed by wash-out, suggesting diagnostic utility but not definitive proof of neuroendocrine differentiation.
population_specificity: 10 patients with metastatic hormone-refractory prostatic adenocarcinoma.
study_duration: Not specified (study repeated after treatment in 3 patients)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5-HTP could reverse insomnia induced by serotonin synthesis inhibition in rats and whether this effect was mediated by central action of 5-HTP.
results_summary: The study found that 5-HTP transiently reversed insomnia caused by p-CPA in rats, but did not lead to a detectable increase in cerebral serotonin, suggesting the sleep restoration may be mediated by 5-HTP's central action.
population_specificity: Rats with induced serotonin synthesis inhibition (p-CPA treatment).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intra-cisternal injection of L-5-HTP and benserazide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of 5-HT1B and 5-HT1A receptors in the inhibitory effects of 5-HTP on male rat ejaculatory behavior.
results_summary: 5-HTP increased ejaculation latency in male rats, an effect enhanced by 5-HT1A receptor antagonists and fully antagonized by a 5-HT1B receptor antagonist. The study suggests postsynaptic 5-HT1B receptors mediate 5-HTP's inhibitory effects, while 5-HT1A autoreceptors partially control these effects.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether subchronic and chronic 5-HTP treatment could attenuate aggression and reduce body weight gain in undernourished dominant pigeons while maintaining feeder control dominance.
results_summary: Both subchronic (4-day) and chronic (16-day) 5-HTP treatments reduced aggression and intra-test body weight gain in dominant pigeons without decreasing feeder control dominance. Recovery scores showed aggression returned to baseline after subchronic treatment but remained lower after chronic treatment, suggesting a learned behavioral adaptation.
population_specificity: Undernourished adult male pigeons with previously established dominance hierarchies.
effective_dosage: 7.5 mg/kg, administered subcutaneously 30 minutes before trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5-HTP administration leads to the formation of serotonin as a "false transmitter" in striatal dopamine neurons.
results_summary: The study found that 5-HTP administration caused a dose-dependent release of serotonin in striatal dopamine neurons, even when dopamine release was not fully abolished, suggesting 5-HT acts as a false transmitter in these neurons.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of 5-HTP on the lymphokine system and its potential role in sleep promotion.
results_summary: Ten minutes after 5-HTP treatment, a decrease was observed in most tested parameters (except IL-3 and CSF secretion), indicating a weak and transient effect on the lymphokine system. The study suggested 5-HTP had relatively weak potency compared to DSIP.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intravenous L-5-HTP could improve myoclonic symptoms in a child with myoclonic encephalopathy of infants (MEI).
results_summary: The study found that L-5-HTP improved myoclonic symptoms at rest and during action but did not affect opsoclonus, suggesting serotonin responsiveness in this MEI case.
population_specificity: A 7-year-old girl with myoclonic encephalopathy of infants (MEI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how 5-HTP interacts with opioid receptors and affects feeding behavior in rats, particularly when combined with subeffective doses of opioids or naloxone.
results_summary: The study found that subeffective doses of 5-HTP, when combined with subcutaneous morphine or naloxone, induced anorexia in food-deprived rats, but this effect was not observed with intraventricular administration. The anorexia induced by FK-33824 was blocked by subcutaneous morphine or naloxone but not by intraventricular administration.
population_specificity: Food-deprived rats
interactions: Opioids (morphine, DAME, DADLE, FK-33824) and naloxone

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of L-dopa and benserazide on serotonin metabolism, specifically the concentrations of 5-HTP, 5-HT, and 5-HIAA in different rat brain areas.
results_summary: The study found that 5-HTP levels increased rapidly, peaked at 1.5 hours, and returned to baseline within 4 hours, while 5-HT levels significantly decreased without changes in 5-HIAA. This suggests L-dopa interferes with serotonin synthesis, likely due to competition for aromatic amino acid decarboxylase.
population_specificity: Rats (hypothalamus, hippocampus, striatum, and olfactory bulbs)
effective_dosage: L-dopa (125 mg/kg, ip) + benserazide (50 mg/kg, ip)
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with measurements up to 4 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) could effectively treat recurring headaches and sleep disorders in children with depressive symptoms and cognitive deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that 5-HTP was effective in reducing headaches and some sleep disorders, particularly frequent awakenings and parasomnias, as confirmed by a double-blind, cross-over trial with placebo.
population_specificity: Forty-eight elementary and junior high school students with recurring headaches, sleep disorders, and depressive symptoms but normal intellectual capacity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how 5-HT depletion methods (5,7-DHT, PCA, PCPA) affect nociception and the antinociceptive effects of 5-HT agonists, including 5-HTP.
results_summary: 5,7-DHT pretreatment enhanced the antinociceptive effect of 5-HTP in mice, observed in tail-flick and hot-plate tests, while PCA and PCPA pretreatments did not significantly alter 5-HTP's effects. The study suggests 5,7-DHT may induce post-synaptic 5-HT receptor supersensitivity.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: Not specified for 5-HTP (other agents: 5,7-DHT 80 µg, PCA 3-4 x 40 mg/kg, PCPA 5-14 x 400 mg/kg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-dose 5-HTP (d-l-5-HTP, l-5-HTP, or combined with benserazide) in treating cerebellar ataxia in patients with hereditary ataxias and other non-degenerative conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant regression of cerebellar ataxia, particularly in static forms and speech speed, after 12 months of treatment. l-5-HTP appeared more effective than d-l-5-HTP, and benefits persisted for 2-4 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: 21 patients with hereditary ataxias, as well as non-degenerative conditions like multiple sclerosis and surgical lesions of the anterior lobe vermis.
effective_dosage: 16 mg/kg/day of d-l-5-HTP or l-5-HTP, or a combination of d-l-5-HTP (16 mg/kg/day) and benserazide (6 mg/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 5-HTP and L-DOPA on EEG patterns during sleep in a child with a rare variant of phenylketonuria.
results_summary: Initial EEG abnormalities persisted after 10 days of treatment but disappeared after 6 months, though sleep traces became disorganized, suggesting delayed or insufficient therapeutic impact.
population_specificity: An 11-month-old child with dihydropteridine reductase deficiency phenylketonuria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of neonatal administration of 5-HTP on pituitary function and developmental milestones in rats.
results_summary: Neonatal 5-HTP treatment accelerated eye opening, decreased serum TSH in males, elevated serum prolactin in males, and lowered serum growth hormone in females. These effects were similar to those caused by L-dopa, suggesting persistent alterations in pituitary function.
population_specificity: Neonatal rats
study_duration: Administered neonatally, effects observed after maturation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of L-5-HTP on depressed patients based on the 5-HT hypothesis and assess its impact on serum 5-HT levels.
results_summary: L-5-HTP showed rapid action, with 10 out of 18 patients showing significant improvement. Nonresponders had relatively lower serum 5-HT levels compared to responders, suggesting a metabolic disturbance in some depressed patients.
population_specificity: 18 depressed patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5-HTP affects prolactin levels in pituitary stalk-sectioned rats and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: 5-HTP initially increased plasma prolactin levels at 30 and 60 minutes post-injection, followed by a decrease. It also moderately increased pituitary prolactin content in stalk-sectioned rats, suggesting a direct or indirect pituitary-level effect.
population_specificity: Pituitary stalk-sectioned rats
study_duration: Short-term (measurements taken up to 60 minutes post-injection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5-HTP (600 mg/day) could reduce narcoleptic and cataplectic attacks and improve sleep duration in narcoleptic-cataplectic patients.
results_summary: The study found no change in the daily number of narcoleptic or cataplectic attacks. However, there was a trend toward reduced daytime sleep duration and a significant increase in nighttime sleep duration.
population_specificity: 11 narcoleptic-cataplectic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-dose 5-HTP (D-L-5-HTP, L-5-HTP, or combined with Benserazide) in treating cerebellar ataxia in patients with heredo-ataxias and other non-degenerative conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant regression of cerebellar ataxia, particularly in static performances and speech speed, after 12 months of treatment. L-5-HTP was more effective than D-L-5-HTP, and improvements were also observed in non-degenerative conditions like multiple sclerosis and surgical injuries.
population_specificity: 21 patients with heredo-ataxias, as well as cases of multiple sclerosis and surgical injury of the anterior lobe vermis.
effective_dosage: 16 mg/kg/day of D-L-5-HTP or L-5-HTP, or 16 mg/kg/day D-L-5-HTP combined with 6 mg/kg/day Benserazide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of repeated high doses of 5-HTP on human sleep, particularly paradoxical sleep and slow wave sleep (SWS).
results_summary: The study found that 5-HTP decreased paradoxical sleep time and percentage during the 2nd week of treatment, followed by a rebound effect post-treatment. In two subjects with initially low SWS, 5-HTP increased SWS, which persisted after treatment. Similar results were observed when 5-HTP was administered with RO.04.4602.
population_specificity: Three healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressive effects of L-5-HTP in hospitalized depressed patients and assess its biochemical impact.
results_summary: Seven of 14 patients showed mild to moderate improvement in depressive symptoms. Non-responders had lower urinary and plasma levels of 5-HT and 5-HIAA compared to responders.
population_specificity: Hospitalized depressed patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressive effects of L-5-HTP in hospitalized depressed patients and assess its biochemical impact.
results_summary: Seven of 14 patients showed mild to moderate improvement in depressive symptoms. Non-responders had lower urinary and plasma levels of 5-HT and 5-HIAA compared to responders, suggesting incomplete utilization of L-5-HTP in non-responders.
population_specificity: Hospitalized depressed patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressant action of nialamide + l-5-HTP compared to nialamide alone in patients with endogenous depression.
results_summary: Patients treated with nialamide + l-5-HTP achieved fuller recovery and a shorter delay of onset compared to those treated with nialamide alone. Side effects were similar except for less orthostatic hypotension in the nialamide + l-5-HTP group.
population_specificity: 30 hospitalized patients with endogenous depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health outcomes associated with intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 diet, focusing on metabolic and weight-related effects.
results_summary: The study found high-quality evidence linking the 5:2 diet to reduced low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels, indicating potential cardiovascular benefits. Other IF regimens showed varying degrees of efficacy in weight loss and metabolic improvements.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of L-5-HTP (100 mg/day) compared to placebo in reducing migraine symptoms in children with primary headache.
results_summary: The study found that L-5-HTP treatment led to a statistically significant decrease in migraine severity, duration, and frequency, as measured by the Migraine Index. Improvement was consistent across both treatment groups, with significance levels ranging from 0.05 to 0.01.
population_specificity: 30 pediatric patients (mean age 10.38 years) with primary headache.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of intermittent calorie restriction (ICR, 5:2 diet) versus continuous calorie restriction (CCR) in reducing liver fat content (LFC) in adults with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and abnormal glucose metabolism.
results_summary: Both ICR and CCR significantly reduced LFC, with no statistically significant difference between the two approaches. ICR showed potential advantages in reducing fat mass and glycosylated hemoglobin, though other metabolic markers did not differ significantly between groups. High adherence was observed for both dietary schemes.
population_specificity: 60 adults with MASLD and abnormal glucose metabolism.
effective_dosage: ICR group: 2 successive fasting days (~500 kcal/day) and 5 recovery days per week; CCR group: continuous calorie restriction (specific kcal not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining intermittent fasting (including the 5:2 diet) with exercise on body weight, body composition, cardiometabolic risk, and fitness measures.
results_summary: Combining intermittent fasting with exercise led to decreased fat mass, but effects on fat-free mass, weight loss, and cardiometabolic risk factors were inconsistent. Intermittent fasting did not impair exercise adaptation and may improve strength, endurance, and cardiopulmonary measures.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from broad inclusion criteria discussion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of different intermittent fasting regimens, including the 5:2 diet, for managing metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: The 5:2 diet significantly improved liver stiffness but did not show significant changes in other metabolic or anthropometric measures. Alternate-day fasting showed broader positive effects on anthropometric measures.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of intermittent fasting regimens, including the 5:2 diet, on cardiometabolic and liver markers in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that intermittent fasting regimens, including the 5:2 diet, reduced steatosis scores and improved anthropometric characteristics of obesity in NAFLD patients, though the evidence was limited by a small number of studies.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied regimens included 5:2 diet, 16/8 time-restricted feeding, and alternate-day fasting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the relationship between intermittent fasting (including the 5:2 Diet) and human gut microbiota, focusing on its effects on diversity, composition, weight loss, and metabolic alterations.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, may enhance metabolic health by modifying gut microbiota, with favorable effects on weight loss and metabolic syndrome characteristics. However, definitive conclusions require further research due to limited and diverse study designs.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on human gut microbiota and metabolic health).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anthropometric, biochemical, and hepatic impacts of intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, in patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, significantly improved body weight, BMI, waist-to-hip ratio, liver enzymes, hepatic steatosis, and stiffness in adults with NAFLD.
population_specificity: Adults with NAFLD (44.64% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the possible mechanisms and drawbacks of intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 diet, as a nonpharmaceutical intervention for chronic noncommunicable diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 diet, may help optimize energy metabolism, prevent obesity, and improve various health outcomes in rodents, with potential benefits for human aging and life expectancy. However, the optimal model of intermittent fasting remains unclear.
population_specificity: Rodents and general human population (aging global population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary macronutrient composition, specifically in the 5:2 diet, influences the reduction of abdominal adipose tissue (total, subcutaneous, and visceral) during weight loss.
results_summary: The 5:2 diet resulted in significant weight loss (-7.2 kg) and reductions in abdominal fat (14.3% total, 17.1% visceral, 12.7% subcutaneous), comparable to the LCHF diet, with no significant differences between the two diets. The study concluded that overall weight loss may be more important than diet composition for fat reduction.
population_specificity: 62 participants with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and critically evaluate preclinical and clinical evidence on intermittent fasting regimens, including the 5:2 Diet, focusing on its effects on bone health.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but indicates that while intermittent fasting shows promise for weight loss and metabolic health, its impact on bone health remains unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize preliminary findings on the effects of intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, on body weight and cardiometabolic risk factors in humans, while also assessing safety and providing practical advice.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, can produce clinically significant weight loss and may improve cardiometabolic risk factors, though only a few studies have examined these benefits in humans.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Two fast days (0-500 kcal) and five feast days (ad libitum intake) per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the strength and quality of evidence from meta-analyses of RCTs assessing the associations of the 5:2 Diet and other intermittent fasting methods with obesity-related health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, was associated with beneficial outcomes such as reduced body mass index, body weight, and improved cardiometabolic markers, though most associations were supported by low to very low quality evidence. Only a few associations, primarily for modified alternate-day fasting, were supported by moderate to high quality evidence.
population_specificity: Adults, including those with overweight, obesity, or nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
study_duration: Median follow-up period of 3 months (IQR 2-5 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, on markers of cardiometabolic health in humans.
results_summary: The 5:2 Diet produced mild to moderate weight loss (1-8% from baseline) and reduced energy intake (10-30% from baseline). It improved markers such as blood pressure, insulin resistance, and oxidative stress, though findings on LDL cholesterol and triglycerides were variable.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare dietary composition and adherence between intermittent calorie restriction (ICR, such as the 5:2 Diet) and continuous calorie restriction (CCR) in individuals with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study compared ICR and CCR but did not provide specific results on the effectiveness or dietary quality of the 5:2 Diet in the abstract. Further details would be needed to assess outcomes.
population_specificity: 98 participants with overweight or obesity (BMI ≥ 25 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate treatment patterns, satisfaction, and tolerability among fibromyalgia patients in Spain, including the role of diet as a non-pharmacologic therapy.
results_summary: The study found that diet was one of the most frequent non-pharmacologic treatments (47% usage), but patient satisfaction with diet was poor (mean NRS score of 5.0). No specific benefits or adverse effects of the 5:2 Diet were detailed.
population_specificity: Middle-aged, married women with fibromyalgia in Spain, presenting moderate to severe pain and sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of isocaloric intermittent fasting (including the 5:2 diet) versus daily caloric restriction on metabolic risk factors for noncommunicable chronic diseases in adults with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent fasting (including the 5:2 diet) produced similar weight loss and metabolic benefits compared to daily caloric restriction, with some evidence suggesting superior improvements in insulin sensitivity and body fat reduction in specific IF regimens. However, conclusions were limited by the available evidence.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight and obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent calorie restriction (5:2 diet) versus continuous calorie restriction on gut microbiota composition and metabolic outcomes in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: Both diets resulted in ~5% weight loss, but microbiome composition did not significantly differ between groups except for Lactobacillales enrichment after ICR. Weight loss was associated with metabolic improvements but not microbiome changes, though baseline Dorea abundance moderately predicted weight loss.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (n=147)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether the 5:2 Diet is a safe and effective approach for weight loss and long-term weight maintenance, comparing it to other dietary strategies.
results_summary: The study found that the 5:2 Diet promotes weight loss but is associated with hunger, which may limit adherence. Potential health benefits are linked to acute food restriction and chronic weight loss, though long-term effects remain unclear.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese populations in developed countries, particularly the United Kingdom.
effective_dosage: 2 days a week of very low-calorie intake ("5:2" regime).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) on endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS) and metabolic abnormalities in liver and pancreas tissues in a cafeteria diet-induced metabolic syndrome model.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF treatment significantly reduced metabolic abnormalities, insulin resistance, and inflammation, and down-regulated ERS markers (GRP78 and CHOP) in liver and pancreas tissues. Histopathological tests confirmed the efficacy of 7,8-DHF in mitigating diet-induced metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice fed a cafeteria diet for 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8 DHF) could protect retinal ganglion cells and preserve inner retinal function in experimental glaucoma models by activating TrkB signaling and reducing amyloid β accumulation.
results_summary: 7,8 DHF administration significantly protected against loss of ganglion cell layer density, preserved inner retinal function, activated TrkB signaling, and reduced soluble Aβ (1-42) levels in rodents exposed to high intraocular pressure, even in BDNF-deficient mice.
population_specificity: Rats and mice with experimental glaucoma models (high intraocular pressure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent calorie restriction (5:2 diet) versus continuous calorie restriction on weight loss, adipose tissue gene expression, and metabolic biomarkers.
results_summary: The 5:2 diet led to slightly greater weight loss (-7.1%) compared to continuous calorie restriction (-5.2%) during the intervention phase, but no significant differences were found in gene expression or metabolic biomarkers. By the final follow-up, weight loss was similar between the two diets (-5.2% vs. -4.9%).
population_specificity: Overweight and obese nonsmokers (BMI 25-40), aged 35-65, 50% women.
effective_dosage: 5 days without energy restriction and 2 days with 75% energy deficit (net weekly deficit ~20%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF activates TrkB signaling to protect neurons against oxygen-glucose deprivation/reperfusion (OGD/R) injury, a model of ischemic stroke.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF treatment increased cell viability, reduced neuronal apoptosis, and modulated apoptosis-associated proteins (downregulated Bax and cleaved caspase-3, upregulated Bcl-2) via TrkB/Akt pathway activation. These effects were reversed by TrkB inhibition or knockdown.
population_specificity: In vitro neuronal model of ischemic stroke (OGD/R injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brain mitochondrial bioenergetic defects exist in Ts65Dn pups (a mouse model of Down syndrome) and whether early treatment with 7,8-DHF improves mitochondrial function.
results_summary: The study found that 7,8-DHF fully restored mitochondrial ATP production, reduced oxygen radicals, and reinstated hippocampal PGC-1α levels in Ts65Dn mice, effectively reversing bioenergetic dysfunction.
population_specificity: Ts65Dn mouse model of Down syndrome (neonatal pups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile existing knowledge on the therapeutic effects of intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, in managing type 2 diabetes mellitus and prediabetes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that intermittent fasting, including the 5:2 Diet, is associated with reduced risk and slowed progression of type 2 diabetes mellitus-related complications, but long-term effects on prediabetes remain unclear.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus and prediabetes (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Fasting for two days and eating normally for the other five days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) in a murine model of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) by assessing its impact on pathological changes in the hippocampus and brain cortex.
results_summary: DHF treatment reversed astrogliosis, reduced expression of HIV-1 coreceptors CXCR4 and CCR5, decreased neuroinflammation, and mitigated mitochondrial damage in the hippocampus and cortex of Tg26 mice. Additionally, DHF increased TrkB phosphorylation, suggesting its therapeutic potential via the TrkB-Akt-NFkB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Tg26 mice, a murine model for HAND.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and underlying mechanisms of 7,8-DHF on osteosarcoma (OS) development.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF reduced cell viability, promoted apoptosis, inhibited migration, and induced oxidative stress in OS cells. It also modulated Akt/Bad and MAPK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Human osteosarcoma cell lines (U2OS and 143B).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of PTSD and assess whether 7,8-DHF could alleviate PTSD-like symptoms by targeting BDNF-TrkB signaling and synaptic deficits.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF prevented fear memory generalization, anxiety-like behaviors, and hippocampal abnormalities in a PTSD model. It also restored BDNF-TrkB signaling and synaptic deficits, with effects blocked by a TrkB inhibitor and partially by an mTOR inhibitor.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to a modified single-prolonged stress (SPS&S) model of PTSD.
study_duration: Not specified (abstract mentions acute or continuous administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone on fracture healing in mice and its impact on osteoprogenitor cell line Kusa4b10 in vitro.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF negatively impacted fracture healing in mice, reducing tissue volume, polar moment of inertia, and biomechanical strength. It showed no effect on osteogenic gene expression or mineralization in Kusa4b10 cells.
population_specificity: Mice with tibial fractures and Kusa4b10 osteoprogenitor cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective and cognitive enhancement properties of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone in a rat model of sporadic Alzheimer's disease induced by intracerebroventricular streptozotocin.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone attenuated cognitive deficits, reduced oxidative stress, improved mitochondrial function, and normalized insulin-related markers and tau pathology in the brain. It also provided protection against neuronal cell death.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with ICV-STZ-induced sporadic Alzheimer's disease-like pathology.
effective_dosage: 5 mg/kg, 10 mg/kg, and 20 mg/kg orally for 21 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone could reverse prepulse inhibition (PPI) deficits caused by dopaminergic stimulation in a maternal immune activation (MIA) model of schizophrenia.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone reversed PPI deficits induced by apomorphine in MIA offspring but not in controls, with a similar trend observed with methamphetamine. Increased BDNF levels in the frontal cortex of MIA rats suggest a potential mechanism for this effect.
population_specificity: Male Long Evans rat offspring from dams exposed to poly I:C (a maternal immune activation model).
interactions: Reversed effects of apomorphine and showed a trend with methamphetamine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 7,8-DHF on cerebral lipid isoprenoid and Rho protein levels in aging mice, focusing on its potential to treat age-related cognitive dysfunction.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF restored levels of Rho proteins Rac1 and Rab3A in aged mice, increased Tiam1 levels, but did not affect BDNF, TrkB, FPP, GGPP, or cholesterol levels. The findings suggest 7,8-DHF may help mitigate age-related synaptic impairment.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice aged 3 and 23 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone on human ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) activity and its potential as a chemopreventive and chemotherapeutic agent.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone exhibited significant ODC suppression with an IC50 of 2.54 µM, acting as a noncompetitive inhibitor. It also showed potential in targeting ODC-evoked anti-apoptosis, suggesting chemopreventive and chemotherapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in silico studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical studies on 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) to assess its potential as a treatment for brain and body pathologies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that over 180 preclinical studies suggest 7,8-DHF shows promise for treating various pathologies, with potential for human therapeutic use. The findings support moving from animal models to human trials.
population_specificity: Animal models (preclinical studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether activation of BDNF signaling via 7,8-DHF affects voluntary alcohol intake reinstatement and relapse in rats with alcohol use disorder.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF did not alter alcohol-primed reinstatement in male rats but significantly enhanced weight-adjusted ethanol potential in female rats during reinstatement, suggesting sex-specific effects on reward craving and relapse. No hyperactivity was observed, indicating the effect was not due to increased locomotor activity.
population_specificity: Male and female Sprague Dawley rats trained for alcohol self-administration.
effective_dosage: Daily IP injection (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8 DHF) with fluoxetine (FLX) enhances antidepressant efficacy in a perimenopausal depression model.
results_summary: The combined FLX and 7,8 DHF treatment significantly improved depressive-like behavior, upregulated autophagy and signaling pathways (PI3K/Akt/mTOR/p-ErK 1/2), increased BDNF and TrkB levels, and reduced inflammation and apoptosis.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal female rats with chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS)-induced depression.
effective_dosage: 7,8 DHF (5 mg/kg/day), FLX (18 mg/kg/day), ANA-12 (0.5 mg/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect and molecular mechanism of 7,8-DHF against alcohol and high-fat diet-induced memory deficits in rats.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF attenuated alcohol and HFD-induced memory loss, restored glutathione levels, reduced oxidative/nitrosative stress markers, and modulated key molecular pathways (NF-κB, Nrf2, BDNF) in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats
study_duration: 4 weeks (last 4 weeks of a 12-week alcohol/HFD regimen)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 7,8-DHF on cued and contextual fear extinction in both male and female mice to assess its potential for treating stress-related disorders.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF attenuated cued fear extinction in females but enhanced it in males when administered before extinction sessions, while post-session administration had no effect in either sex. Contextual fear extinction was unaffected by 7,8-DHF in both sexes.
population_specificity: Male and female mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could restore motor deficits and tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) expression in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease (PD) via TrkB-dependent mechanisms.
results_summary: DHF treatment restored motor function and TH expression in the dorsolateral striatum despite severe dopamine loss, increased phosphorylated TrkB and secondary messengers, and elevated the sprouting biomarker SCG10 in both the striatum and substantia nigra/midbrain.
population_specificity: Mice with progressive MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease.
study_duration: 4 weeks of DHF treatment following 4 weeks of MPTP administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the interactions of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) with serum albumin and its inhibitory effects on cytochrome P450 enzymes and xanthine oxidase.
results_summary: DHF forms a stable complex with albumin and can displace Site I and Site II ligands. It also acts as a potent inhibitor of CYP2C9, CYP2C19, CYP3A4, and xanthine oxidase, with effects comparable to positive controls.
population_specificity: In vitro models (not specified for human or animal subjects).
interactions: Potential pharmacokinetic interactions with coadministered drugs due to enzyme inhibition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) against high-fat diet (HFD) and ethanol-induced liver toxicity in rats.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF significantly reduced oxidative stress and inflammation in the liver, lowered IL-1β levels, and modulated gene expression related to oxidative stress and inflammation, demonstrating protective effects against HFD and ethanol-induced liver damage.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (150-200 g) fed a high-fat diet and ethanol.
study_duration: 4 weeks (last four weeks of a 12-week study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 7,8-DHF on osteoarthritis (OA) and its role in the Nrf2 signaling pathway in chondrocytes.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF activated the Nrf2 pathway, reduced cartilage degradation, and lowered expression of inflammatory and degradative markers (MMPs, IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α) in OA mice. It also upregulated HO-1 expression, suggesting therapeutic potential for OA.
population_specificity: Primary mouse chondrocytes and OA-induced mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of 7,8-DHF on rotenone-induced motor deficits in a Parkinson's disease model.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF improved behavioral performance, reduced dopaminergic neuron loss, activated TrkB receptors and signaling cascades, and decreased p-MAPK, p-α-synuclein, and p-tau levels in the substantia nigra.
population_specificity: Nine-month-old rats with rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF protects SH-SY5Y neuronal cells from high glucose-induced toxicity and oxidative stress.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF exhibited antioxidant effects, reduced oxidative stress, restored mitochondrial polarization, and modulated apoptotic proteins (Bax and Bcl-2), protecting cells from high glucose-induced damage.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y neuronal cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute application of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) induces epileptiform activity in brain slices and its effects on pre-existing epileptiform discharges.
results_summary: DHF did not initiate epileptiform activity but increased the frequency and duration of 4-aminopyridine (4AP)-induced ictal and interictal events in both the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus CA1 region, sometimes leading to ictogenesis.
population_specificity: Acute horizontal hippocampal-entorhinal cortex slices from 30-35-day-old mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effects and mechanisms of 7,8-DHF on doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in both in vivo and in vitro models.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF improved cell viability, mitochondrial function, and cardiac performance in Dox-treated models, mediated through activation of Akt and regulation of STAT3, AMPK, and ERK signaling pathways. Its protective effects were abolished by TrkB antagonist ANA-12.
population_specificity: Kunming mice and H9c2 cells (rat cardiomyoblasts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) affects gastric dynamics, specifically its role in enhancing carbachol-induced contraction and gastric emptying.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF enhanced carbachol-induced gastric muscle contraction via TrkB/Akt pathway, increased M3 receptor expression, and improved gastric emptying in rats. The effect was partially blocked by TrkB and PLC-γ antagonists.
population_specificity: Rat gastric muscle strips and in vivo rat models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could protect immature retinas against hypoxic-ischemic (HI) injury and promote neurogenesis via the tyrosine kinase receptor B/ERK signaling pathway.
results_summary: DHF treatment partially protected immature retinas at histologic and functional levels between P14 and P30, promoted survival of proliferating inner retinal cells, and enhanced transdifferentiation to bipolar cells. However, it did not prevent apoptosis, inflammation, or blood-retinal barrier damage at P8, and its neuroprotective effects were eliminated by ERK inhibition.
population_specificity: Postnatal day 7 rat pups subjected to HI injury.
effective_dosage: Intraperitoneal injection 2 hours before and 18 hours after HI injury (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Assessed outcomes at various timepoints up to P30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) alters the structural dynamics of pyramidal neurons in real-time and its effects on object recognition memory.
results_summary: DHF increased the gain rates of dendritic spines and axonal boutons in pyramidal neurons and improved object recognition memory, suggesting it enhances structural plasticity and cognitive function.
population_specificity: Pyramidal neurons of the barrel cortex in animal models.
study_duration: Chronic oral treatment (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the early effects of 7,8-DHF on Alzheimer's disease-related pathology, dendritic arborization, synaptic density, and neurochemical changes in a mouse model of AD.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF treatment reduced cortical Aβ plaque deposition, protected cortical neurons from reduced dendritic arbor complexity, and mitigated hippocampal neurochemical changes (choline-containing compounds and glutamate loss), but did not significantly affect dendritic spine density or hippocampal neurogenesis.
population_specificity: 5xFAD mouse model of Alzheimer's disease (treated at 1 month of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if activating TrkB receptors with 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone could reverse Pb2+-induced impairments of vesicular release in hippocampal synapses.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone reversed Pb2+-induced impairments of presynaptic transmitter release at Schaffer collateral-CA1 synapses, restoring vesicular release probability and calcium influx. The study demonstrated that TrkB receptor activation by 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone effectively counteracted long-term Pb2+ exposure effects.
population_specificity: Rats prenatally and postnatally exposed to Pb2+ until 50 days of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could normalize brain energy deficits, enhance functional connectivity, and improve memory performance when combined with exercise after traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: 7,8-DHF treatment, both alone and combined with exercise, mitigated TBI-induced effects, improving memory performance, increasing markers of cell energy metabolism, and enhancing hippocampal functional connectivity. The combination of 7,8-DHF and exercise showed the most significant benefits.
population_specificity: Animals subjected to moderate fluid percussion injury (FPI) as a model for TBI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the TrkB activation profile of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) and its therapeutic potential in Huntington's disease (HD) models.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF selectively phosphorylated TrkBY816, activated the PLCγ1 pathway, improved motor and cognitive deficits in HD mice, and normalized striatal levels of enkephalin, iNOS, nNOS, and p75/TrkB imbalance.
population_specificity: In vitro primary cultures and R6/1 mice (a model of Huntington's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could prevent increased C1q expression in the prefrontal cortex of adult offspring after maternal immune activation (MIA).
results_summary: 7,8-DHF administered during juvenile and adolescent stages prevented the increase of C1q in the prefrontal cortex of adult offspring after MIA, suggesting potential prophylactic effects on behavioral abnormalities.
population_specificity: Adult offspring of pregnant mice exposed to poly(I:C) to induce MIA.
study_duration: Administered from 4 to 8 weeks of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms of cognitive impairment in ApoE-KO mice and assess the protective effects of 7,8-DHF on spatial learning and memory.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF significantly improved cognitive decline in ApoE-KO mice, linked to activation of the Akt/GSK-3β pathway and reduced expression of abnormal tau proteins. The treatment also lowered active-AEP and truncated tau N368 levels.
population_specificity: ApoE-KO mice and C57BL/6 mice (5-weeks-old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressant-like effects of chronic 7,8-DHF treatment in a chronic mild stress (CMS) model of depression and its impact on TrkB signaling and synaptic protein expression.
results_summary: Chronic 7,8-DHF treatment restored depressive-like behaviors in mice, increased TrkB phosphorylation and BDNF levels, and activated synaptic proteins like PSD95 and synaptophysin. The effects were blocked by the TrkB antagonist K252a, confirming the role of TrkB signaling.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to chronic mild stress (CMS) as a depression model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone could prevent schizophrenia-like behavioral and neurodevelopmental abnormalities in offspring of poly(I:C)-treated mice by enhancing BDNF-TrkB signaling.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone supplementation during juvenile and adolescent stages prevented cognitive deficits, PPI deficits, and restored BDNF-TrkB signaling, PV, and PGC-1α immunoreactivity in the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus of adult offspring from poly(I:C)-treated mice.
population_specificity: Offspring of pregnant mice exposed to poly(I:C) to model schizophrenia-like neurodevelopmental abnormalities.
effective_dosage: 1 mg/mL in drinking water (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Administered during juvenile and adolescent stages (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-dihydroxyflavone could reverse depression- and anxiety-like behaviors and biochemical abnormalities induced by chronic mild stress in rats.
results_summary: 7,8-dihydroxyflavone reversed CMS-induced depression-like behavior in sucrose consumption tests, reduced immobility in forced-swimming tests, and attenuated anxiety-like behavior in elevated T-maze tests. It also reduced serum corticosterone levels and increased hippocampal BDNF levels in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats subjected to chronic mild stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could ameliorate PTSD-like memory impairment and synaptic plasticity changes in rats exposed to immobilization stress.
results_summary: DHF administration 8 hours after stress reversed spatial memory impairment and normalized increased long-term potentiation (LTP) in the CA3-CA1 pathway, with no effect observed in unstressed controls.
population_specificity: Young adult rats (60 days old) exposed to immobilization stress as a PTSD model.
study_duration: Single administration, effects assessed 2-8 days post-stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects and mechanisms of action of 7,8-DHF in melanoma cells, particularly its impact on growth, survival, migration, invasion, and melanogenesis.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF inhibited growth, clonogenic survival, migration, and invasion of melanoma cells, and exhibited anti-melanogenic activity by downregulating MITF and its downstream targets. Combination treatment with resveratrol enhanced these effects.
population_specificity: Alpha-MSH-stimulated B16F10 melanoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could protect against MPTP-induced motor deficits, dopaminergic neuron loss, and α-synuclein overexpression in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: DHF improved motor function, reduced dopaminergic neuron loss, suppressed α-synuclein overexpression, and enhanced antioxidative activity in MPTP-treated mice. These effects were linked to TrkB activation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with MPTP-induced Parkinson's-like symptoms.
study_duration: From the first day of MPTP injection until 9 days after the last MPTP injection (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could reduce clinical severity and pathological damage in a mouse model of MOG-induced EAE by activating TrkB and downstream signaling pathways.
results_summary: DHF treatment reduced clinical impairment, increased TrkB phosphorylation, activated AKT and STAT3 pathways, and decreased inflammation, demyelination, and axonal loss compared to controls, mimicking the effects of brain-derived neurotrophic factor.
population_specificity: C57Bl/6 mice with MOG-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE).
study_duration: Daily treatment starting on the day of disease induction until day 28.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of 7,8-DHF in Parkinson’s disease models by activating the BDNF receptor TrkB.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF improved dopamine-mediated behaviors in a 6-OHDA rat model, prevented dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra, and activated TrkB phosphorylation. It also protected against acute MPTP neurotoxicity in mice but did not affect climbing behavior in the pole test.
population_specificity: 6-OHDA-induced rat model and MPTP-induced mouse model of Parkinsonism.
effective_dosage: Administered in drinking water (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: Four weeks (two weeks before and two weeks after lesion induction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-injury treatment with 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could protect immature neurons and promote neurogenesis following moderate traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: Post-injury DHF treatment for 2 weeks increased the number of adult-born immature neurons in the hippocampus and enhanced their dendrite arborization in mice with moderate TBI.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to moderate controlled cortical impact (CCI)-TBI or sham surgery.
effective_dosage: Once daily via intraperitoneal injection (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular interactions of 7,8-DHF and its derivatives with TrkB and VEGFR2 receptors, focusing on its dual biochemical actions.
results_summary: The study found that 7,8-DHF acts as a TrkB agonist, enhancing phosphorylation and downstream signaling, while downregulating VEGFR2 phosphorylation in photoreceptor cells and retinal tissue, revealing its dual biochemical action.
population_specificity: 661W photoreceptor cells and retinal tissue (in vitro/in vivo study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-obesity effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) on 3T3-L1 preadipocyte cells, focusing on adipogenesis inhibition, lipid accumulation reduction, and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF (<20 μM) reduced intracellular lipid droplets, down-regulated adipogenic transcription factors (C/EBP-α, C/EBP-β, PPAR-γ), and decreased ROS levels while increasing antioxidant enzyme expression. Higher concentrations (>20 μM) induced apoptotic cell death.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 preadipocyte cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could prevent dendrite degeneration and improve functional outcomes following traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: DHF treatment reduced dendrite swellings, prevented dendritic spine loss, and improved rotarod performance after TBI, though it did not significantly reduce neuron death.
population_specificity: Animals (model of traumatic brain injury induced by controlled cortical impact)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) on sleep patterns and brain orexin levels in mice, particularly in relation to its potential antidepressant-like properties.
results_summary: DHF significantly decreased total sleep and non-rapid eye movement sleep in mice during the dark phase, altered sleep-related brain wave activity, and reduced hypothalamic orexin A levels without affecting orexin B or immobility tests.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: 5 mg/kg administered at the beginning of the dark phase
study_duration: 24 hours (baseline recording) followed by treatment until sacrifice the next day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of 7,8-DHF as a novel treatment for neurodevelopmental disorders by mimicking BDNF signaling.
results_summary: The study suggests that 7,8-DHF may effectively activate the BDNF pathway, potentially preventing, arresting, or reversing abnormal neurodevelopmental events caused by genetic or environmental factors. However, clinical efficacy and safety data are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Neurodevelopmental disorders (specific population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic activation of muscular TrkB by 7,8-DHF could prevent diet-induced obesity and improve metabolic outcomes in mice.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF treatment increased UCP1 expression and AMPK activity in skeletal muscle, leading to higher energy expenditure, reduced adiposity, and improved insulin sensitivity in female mice on a high-fat diet. The anti-obesity effect was dependent on muscular TrkB, as it was absent in muscle-specific TrkB knockout mice.
population_specificity: Female mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 7,8-DHF could prevent further dopaminergic cell and terminal loss and restore motor deficits when introduced mid-intervention in a progressive mouse model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF administration maintained 54% of tyrosine hydroxylase levels in the striatum, increased levels of SCG10, pTrkB, and pERK1/2, and restored motor deficits in MPTP-treated mice. The intervention blocked further dopaminergic terminal loss and improved motor function.
population_specificity: Progressive MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease mouse model.
study_duration: 2 weeks (intervention started at the 2-week midpoint of a 4-week MPTP treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) affects APP processing and cognitive functions in vitro and in vivo, specifically for Alzheimer's disease (AD) treatment.
results_summary: DHF had no significant effect on amyloid β precursor protein (APP), BACE1, or amyloid β protein (Aβ). It did not reduce Aβ deposition or improve learning and memory impairments in AD model mice.
population_specificity: AD model mice (APP23/PS45)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of 7,8-DHF as a TrkB agonist in mitigating traumatic brain injury (TBI) in mice.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF attenuated functional deficits, brain damage, and apoptosis in TBI mice, enhanced TrkB signaling via the PI3K/Akt pathway, and showed benefits even with delayed administration.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to controlled cortical impact (TBI model) and primary cortical neurons subjected to stretch injury.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg intraperitoneally, administered 10 min post-injury and daily for 3 days.
study_duration: 3 days (with effects assessed up to 28 days post-injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) could effectively target dendritic pathology and cognitive impairments in Fragile X syndrome (FXS) mutant mice.
results_summary: The study found that 7,8-DHF improved spatial and fear memory and corrected spine abnormalities in FXS mice, likely through modulation of AMPA receptor subunits and phosphorylation pathways. No effects were observed in wild-type mice, suggesting FXS-specific benefits.
population_specificity: Fragile X mental retardation 1 (Fmr1) gene knock-out mice (FXS model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of 7,8-DHF in a transgenic ALS mouse model (SOD1(G93A)).
results_summary: Chronic administration of 7,8-DHF significantly improved motor deficits, preserved spinal motor neuron count, and maintained dendritic spines in SOD1(G93A) mice, suggesting its potential as a therapy for ALS and other motor neuron diseases.
population_specificity: Transgenic ALS mouse model (SOD1(G93A)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) could improve cognitive function and synaptic density in a mouse model of severe neuronal loss mimicking Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Systemic 7,8-DHF treatment improved spatial memory in lesioned mice and selectively increased thin spine density in the CA1 region without affecting other spine types, suggesting potential benefits even after significant neuronal loss.
population_specificity: CaM/Tet-DTA mice (an inducible model of severe neuronal loss in the hippocampus and cortex).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) could reverse cognitive and synaptic impairments in a schizophrenia model by activating TrkB signaling.
results_summary: Chronic 7,8-DHF treatment enhanced TrkB phosphorylation, increased downstream signaling (ERK1/2, CaMKII, CREB, GluR1), improved hippocampal synaptic plasticity, and rescued spatial working learning deficits in MK-801-treated rats.
population_specificity: MK-801-treated rats as a model for schizophrenia-related cognitive deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of 7,8-DHF against 6-OHDA-induced cytotoxicity in PC12 cells and explore its underlying antioxidant mechanism.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF effectively prevented 6-OHDA-induced cell death, apoptosis, and mitochondrial dysfunction in PC12 cells. It reduced oxidative stress markers and enhanced antioxidant activity, suggesting its neuroprotective effects are mediated by potent antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: PC12 cells (a rat adrenal pheochromocytoma cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) inhibits oxidative stress-induced 8-oxoguanine (8-oxoG) formation and its mechanism of action via the PI3K-Akt pathway.
results_summary: DHF significantly reduced 8-oxoG formation induced by hydrogen peroxide, elevated OGG1 mRNA and protein levels, and increased Nrf2 binding to antioxidant response elements. It also restored nuclear Nrf2 levels and phosphorylated Akt, which were decreased by oxidative stress, indicating activation of DNA repair systems.
population_specificity: Hamster lung fibroblasts (V79-4)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could mitigate behavioral abnormalities and dopaminergic neurotoxicity induced by methamphetamine in mice.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF attenuated methamphetamine-induced hyperlocomotion, behavioral sensitization, and dopaminergic neurotoxicity in mice, with effects blocked by a TrkB antagonist. It also reduced microglial activation in the striatum.
population_specificity: Mice administered methamphetamine
study_duration: Single administration or 5 days (for behavioral sensitization)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 7,8-DHF on porcine oocyte maturation and developmental competence by assessing intracellular GSH levels, ROS generation, and apoptosis-related gene expression.
results_summary: Treatment with 1 μM 7,8-DHF improved cytoplasmic maturation, increased blastocyst formation (36.1%), elevated intracellular GSH levels, reduced ROS generation, and modulated apoptosis-related gene expression (higher BCL2L1 and lower BAK1).
population_specificity: Porcine oocytes and embryos in vitro.
effective_dosage: 0, 1, 5, and 10 μM during IVM and IVC.
study_duration: Duration of in vitro maturation and culture (specific timeframe not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone on synaptic and intrinsic neuronal properties, particularly its role in modulating GABAergic inhibition and neuronal excitability.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone significantly reduced GABAergic inhibition by decreasing presynaptic GABA release and increased neuronal excitability, effects mediated by TrkB receptors. Glutamatergic transmission remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons in acute cortical slices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could improve prepulse inhibition (PPI) deficits in mice induced by methamphetamine (METH) and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF improved METH-induced PPI deficits in a dose-dependent manner, an effect blocked by the TrkB antagonist ANA-12. It also attenuated METH-induced dopamine release in the striatum, suggesting its potential therapeutic role in neuropsychiatric disorders.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to methamphetamine
interactions: TrkB antagonist ANA-12 blocked 7,8-DHF's effects; inactive ligand 5,7-DHF had no effect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) activates TrkB receptors and promotes survival and neurite growth in motoneurons, as well as its pathway activation profile compared to BDNF.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF activated TrkB receptors, promoted survival and neurite growth in cultured motoneurons, and selectively activated the PI3K/AKT pathway but not the MAPK pathway, differing from BDNF's effects and hippocampal neuron responses.
population_specificity: Primary cultured mouse motoneurons
effective_dosage: Dose-dependent effects noted, but specific amounts not provided

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms of apoptosis induction by 7,8-DHF in U937 human leukemic cells, focusing on its effects on signaling pathways and Bcl-2 family proteins.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF inhibited growth and induced apoptosis in U937 cells through up-regulation of death receptor proteins, down-regulation of anti-apoptotic IAP family proteins, and activation of caspases and MAPK pathways. Bcl-2 overexpression protected cells from apoptosis, and ERK/JNK inhibitors reduced 7,8-DHF-induced apoptosis.
population_specificity: U937 human leukemic cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could prevent age-related declines in fear memory and amygdalar synaptic plasticity in aged rats.
results_summary: Chronic 7,8-DHF treatment enhanced TrkB phosphorylation, increased spine density in fear-processing brain regions, improved amygdalar synaptic plasticity, and prevented declines in fear conditioning performance.
population_specificity: Aged (24-month-old) male Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone enhances neuromuscular transmission by selectively activating TrkB receptors.
results_summary: The study found that 7,8-DHF enhanced neuromuscular transmission by approximately 32% in diaphragm muscle via TrkB activation, suggesting potential as a therapy for improving neuromuscular function.
population_specificity: TrkB(F616A) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory mechanisms of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) in LPS-stimulated RAW264.7 cells.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF significantly reduced LPS-induced inflammatory mediators (NO, PGE₂, IL-1β) and suppressed NF-κB activity and MAPK phosphorylation, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects via these pathways.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells (a murine macrophage cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could counteract aging-related cognitive impairment in rats and whether its effects were age-dependent.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF improved spatial memory in aged rats, with stronger effects in younger (22-month-old) rats than older (30-month-old) rats. The improvements were linked to enhanced synapse formation, synaptic plasticity, and activation of memory-related proteins in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Aged rats (22 and 30 months old) with cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: Daily i.p. administration (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: 2 weeks for 22-month-old rats; longer duration (unspecified) for 30-month-old rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-DHF could attenuate disease progression in Mecp2 mutant mice, a model for Rett syndrome, by activating the BDNF receptor (TrkB).
results_summary: 7,8-DHF extended lifespan, delayed weight loss, improved neuronal nuclei size, enhanced voluntary locomotor activity, and partially normalized breathing patterns in Mecp2 mutant mice.
population_specificity: Mecp2 mutant mice (a model for Rett syndrome).
effective_dosage: Administered in drinking water (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of 7,8-DHF on memory deficits and BDNF-TrkB signaling in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF rescued memory deficits in 5XFAD mice, restored deficient TrkB signaling, and reduced BACE1 expression, Aβ40, and Aβ42 levels. It also lowered baseline BACE1 in wild-type mice, suggesting broader regulatory effects.
population_specificity: 5XFAD transgenic mice (12-15 months old) and non-transgenic littermate controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) could prevent long-term memory impairment induced by severe stress in rats by activating the BDNF-TrkB pathway.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF prevented stress-induced long-term memory deficits in rats when administered either 2 hours before or 8 hours after stress exposure, suggesting its potential as a post-stress therapeutic intervention.
population_specificity: Adult male rats exposed to immobilization stress (IMO).
study_duration: Single administration (either 2 h pre-IMO or 8 h post-IMO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone acts as a TrkB agonist and exhibits neuroprotective effects in various neurological disease models.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone activated TrkB signaling, protected neurons from apoptosis, reduced toxicity in kainic acid-induced injury, decreased stroke infarct volumes, and showed neuroprotection in a Parkinson’s disease model, all in a TrkB-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Mice (wild-type and TrkB-deficient)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytoprotective mechanism of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) against oxidative stress-induced cell damage, focusing on its effect on heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) expression and the ERK/Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: DHF upregulated HO-1 expression in a dose- and time-dependent manner, increased Nrf2 protein expression and nuclear translocation, and activated ERK, leading to protection against oxidative stress. The protective effect was attenuated by ERK inhibition, confirming the role of the ERK/Nrf2/HO-1 pathway.
population_specificity: Lung fibroblast V79-4 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8 DHF) could upregulate TrkB signaling and protect retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) from excitotoxic and oxidative stress-induced damage.
results_summary: 7,8 DHF robustly upregulated TrkB signaling, enhanced downstream survival pathways (AKT and MAPK/ERK), and protected RGCs from excitotoxic and oxidative stress-induced apoptosis. It also promoted neurite outgrowth, suggesting therapeutic potential for optic neuropathies.
population_specificity: Primary rat retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and the RGC-5 cell line (retinal neuronal precursor).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of flavones, including 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone, as nutraceuticals with neuroprotective effects by modulating key pathways in neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The abstract suggests flavones, including 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone, show promise for neuroprotection due to their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neurotrophic activities, but their pharmacodynamics are not well-established.
population_specificity: Not specified (general neurodegenerative disorder context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of 7,8-DHF as a therapeutic agent for mitigating opioid tolerance and opioid-induced hyperalgesia (OIH) through its neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects.
results_summary: The study suggests that 7,8-DHF, a TrkB ligand, may protect against opioid tolerance and OIH by exerting neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects, though it primarily reviews existing evidence rather than presenting new experimental data.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuroprotective effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) in neuropsychiatric disorders, focusing on depression, neurodegenerative diseases, and learning and memory functions.
results_summary: 7,8-DHF mimics BDNF to activate TrkB and downstream pathways, showing neuroprotective effects in preclinical studies for Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, depression, and memory impairment. It also functions via oxidative stress reduction, estrogen receptor cooperation, and gut flora regulation.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (animal models and in vitro research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuroprotective potential of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone (DHF) and its mechanisms of action in treating various neurological disorders.
results_summary: DHF demonstrates significant neuroprotective effects, including promoting neuronal survival, synaptic plasticity, and neurogenesis, while also exhibiting anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. It shows promise in mitigating neurodegenerative processes in disorders like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and cerebral ischemia.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of preclinical and potential therapeutic applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of psychoplastogens, including naturally occurring compounds, for rapid and effective treatment of major depressive disorder.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the limitations of existing antidepressants and introduces psychoplastogens as promising alternatives with acute and long-term positive effects, but does not specifically detail findings for 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone as a small-molecule BDNF mimetic with antidepressant-like activity.
results_summary: The study highlights 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone as a promising BDNF mimetic with antidepressant-like effects, suggesting it could be a therapeutic target for depression due to its role in neuroplasticity regulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general depression research context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone as a potential pharmacological treatment targeting brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) pathways in PTSD.
results_summary: The study suggests 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone shows promise as a treatment for PTSD by targeting BDNF pathways, supported by animal and proof-of-concept studies, though conclusive evidence is lacking.
population_specificity: Individuals with PTSD (heterogeneous phenotype).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of BDNF-TrkB signaling in inflammation-induced depression and assess the potential therapeutic effects of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone as a TrkB agonist.
results_summary: The study suggests that 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone may counteract depression-like phenotypes induced by LPS-induced inflammation by modulating BDNF-TrkB signaling in key brain regions. The authors propose it as a potential therapeutic agent for inflammation-related depression.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical models, given the focus on LPS-induced inflammation and brain regions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of sex hormones and 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone as treatment strategies for dementia, focusing on their neuroprotective and cognitive-enhancing qualities.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone, as a brain-derived neurotrophic factor receptor agonist, shows promise for clinical use in dementia treatment, though specific results are not detailed. The review highlights the need for further research to translate evidence into practice.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on dementia in ageing populations)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone as a small-molecule mimetic of BDNF, focusing on its ability to activate TrkB and its efficacy in CNS disease models.
results_summary: 7,8-Dihydroxyflavone demonstrated remarkable therapeutic efficacy in various CNS disease models by modulating multiple functions and activating TrkB, showing promise as a BDNF alternative. The study also highlighted other small molecules with potential TrkB activation mechanisms.
population_specificity: Preclinical models of central nervous system diseases (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of acidic diets and alkaline supplements on bone health through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Acidic diets significantly increased net acid excretion and urinary calcium excretion but had no significant effect on bone turnover markers or bone mineral density. The study suggests acidic diets may not be harmful to bone health.
population_specificity: Aging population, specifically those at risk for osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary intervention, specifically acidic and alkaline diets, could influence serum and urine uric acid levels to prevent hyperuricemia.
results_summary: The study found that acidic diets increased serum uric acid levels while decreasing uric acid excretion, whereas alkaline diets facilitated uric acid excretion. The ratio of uric acid clearance to creatinine clearance was lower for acidic diets, indicating reduced excretion efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely Japanese participants, given the context of the Japanese Government's health promotion program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether auricular acupressure, alone or combined with emotional freedom techniques (EFT), could reduce pain, alleviate anxiety, and improve patient satisfaction in postoperative lower limb fracture patients.
results_summary: The combined group (auricular acupressure + EFT) showed significantly lower pain and anxiety scores compared to the auricular acupressure and control groups, along with higher nursing care satisfaction.
population_specificity: Postoperative patients with lower limb fractures (n=99).
study_duration: Measurements taken at 4, 12, 24, 48, and 72 hours post-intervention; total intervention duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to categorize and synthesize 30 years of research on acupressure in children to identify its applications and benefits.
results_summary: Acupressure was found to offer six main benefits for children, including alleviating nausea and vomiting, relieving pain, decreasing anxiety, relieving fatigue, increasing visual function, and increasing weight and height. The majority of studies were randomized controlled trials, with 72% originating from Asia and 66% published in the last decade.
population_specificity: Children, primarily school-age (7-12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of active acupressure compared to sham acupressure in alleviating symptoms of diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS-D).
results_summary: Active acupressure significantly reduced symptom severity, improved stool consistency and frequency, and enhanced psychological outcomes like anxiety and depression compared to sham acupressure. It also reduced the use of rescue medications.
population_specificity: 63 patients with IBS-D recruited from Alexandria Main University Hospital, Egypt.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pressure applied to specific acupoints after two days of training).
study_duration: Four weeks of intervention following two days of training.
